Mr. Anderson seconded.

Motion carried.

Mr. Smith then moved to call a special meeting of this council to consider the question raised by Mr. Anderson.

Mr. Hunter seconded.

Motion carried.

Mr. Smith then moved to adjourn until next day noon.

Motion carried.

The council then adjourned until Friday evening.

LEARNING AT LAST.

They are gradually coming to the view that there can be no satisfactory terms by which the project can be transacted, and the pre- cedings of the Farmers’ Union, last week.

Mr. Parry said he had been re- quested to bring this matter before the house because a special com- mittee on the railway commi- ttee was not going the right way about the question. He spoke of the line between Brandon and the Saskatahene boundary, which he said, seems to have lost sight of the fact that in applying for the Grand Trunk Western line he was losing time. The Local Govern- ment Board has already told him that it was not proper to push the limit of its power until it knew whether such a line would be served by the Dominion Government, so the questions now raised by the Jum der Union, if they are really raised, are whether such a line will be served, or is it going to be pushed beyond the limit of the rights of the Dominion, and if it is not, why not? Is the idea of a split city going to be pushed? Are they going to give up the fact that the Dominion does not want to handle the matter? If they do give it up, what is the theory behind this? It is not practical, and the sooner we get away from the idea that it is going to be a split city, and once the shape of things, that much will be done toward settling the matter.

It was suggested that a resolution be moved that the Union do all in its power to oppose any attempt to split the City into the two sides, but Mr. Parry said that all such resolutions were futile unless they were backed up by other resolutions.

The House adjourned.

SHOVED HIM OFF WORK.

She Wanted More Food—Has Hope Gone Away?

What is that woman doing? she asked the judge, turning round in amazement. We found her on the bench and brought her here. She seems to be in great pain."

The woman sat on a bench in the entryway of the building, her head bowed, her hands clasped behind her back. Her dress was torn at the knee; her shoes were very faded; there stood on the ground near her feet a small child.

"Does she belong to you?" asked the judge.

"I believe she does," replied the officer, not seeming to care.

"No! You're lying!" cried the child, jumping down.

"Nay, not now," said the judge, raising his hand. "Go on with your work. I will hear you when you are done."

The woman continued to sit, her eyes fixed on the ground.

"What do you want me to do?" she asked, her voice wavering.

"I want you to go back to your husband," said the judge, sternly.

"He wouldn't let me work for him," she replied, tears streaming down her face.

"He has no right to keep you from working," said the judge, firmly.

"But he's cruel!" cried the woman, clutching at the child.

"I'm sure he's not," replied the judge, dismissively. "Go back to your work."

The woman sighed, stood up, and walked away. The child followed, crying softly.

INDIAN GIRLS.

As an example of their docility, even when faced with the loss of their family, these girls prove their adaptability. One girl, found wandering in the street, was seen by a passing Indian woman who approached her and offered her some food. The child accepted the food, smiled, and disappeared into a nearby alley. Another was found crying in a doorway, surrounded by a group of Indians who gave her food and comfort. Despite the trials and tribulations they face daily, these girls maintain their sense of dignity and resilience.

AT SAN JACINTO.

How Texas Was Captured and Held—General.

An aged Texas warrior's reminiscences of the War for the Independence of Texas.

The Commercial Gazette has the following account of an interview with Mr. Hopson, who was an active participant in the battle of San Jacinto, and who has been engaged in the business of tailoring for many years. He was present at the battle of San Jacinto, and his recollection of the events of that day are still vivid in his mind.

Mr. Hopson describes the scene of the battle as follows:

"The battle of San Jacinto was fought on April 21st, 1836, near Houston, Texas. The Texans, under the command of General Sam Houston, defeated the Mexicans under General Santa Anna. The battle lasted from sunrise until noon, and ended in a decisive victory for the Texans. The Mexicans lost over 600 men killed and wounded, while the Texans lost only about 15."

Mr. Hopson also relates how he came to be present at the battle:

"I was living in Houston at the time of the battle, and I heard about it through the newspapers. I decided to go to the battle, and I set out on horseback early in the morning. I arrived just in time to see the battle begin, and I was able to witness the entire engagement."

Mr. Hopson goes on to describe the conditions at the battle:

"The Texans were well armed and well trained, while the Mexicans were poorly equipped and ill-prepared. The Texans were able to take advantage of their superior training and equipment, and they were able to defeat the Mexicans with relative ease."

Mr. Hopson concludes by saying:

"It was a great day for Texas, and it will always be remembered as the day when Texas gained its independence. I am proud to have been there, and I am grateful for the opportunity to share my experiences with others."

Bufflehead, or Black-necked Nasty Kestrel.

There are not many instances of the prairie's most common birds of bison, hawks and elk that once "shook the earth" in the province. Are they extinct? No, not yet. They are in better shape than ever before, and are now an object of deep interest. Last Friday morning, a fine specimen of the rarest moose, that had been shot in the vicinity of Brandon, was found. All day long the body was surrounded by wondering crowds, who truly felt that they had seen a sight of a passing nature. There lay the last survivor of a race which, some years ago, found an asylum in the province. The animal was killed at the age of twelve years, and the greatest wonder is that it should have lived so long. It is not impossible, that his mate, a very rare species, will soon join him.

MUSICAL.

The members of the L.O.A.S. have arranged for a grand concert on the evening of the 21st inst., and have secured the best talent of Winnipeg. A sufficient guarantee of the excellence of the performers is given by the fact that they are engaged to accompany the Civic Band, and will be heard in the concert hall at 8 o'clock. The programme will consist of selections from the operas of Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini, and others, as well as selections from the works of Mendelssohn, Schumann, and other composers.
